pages.name: welcome

html.fr:
Ceci est un travail en cours et de nombreux changements ont lieu chaque jour. Vous pouvez suivre le développement de l'application et même y participer en nous rejoignant sur le lien GitHub ici-haut.

Si vous découvrez un bogue ou si vous rencontrez un problème, nous vous prions de bien vouloir créer un billet sur le projet

Puis-je utiliser ce projet pour mon gouvernement ou ma compagnie?

Oui, il s'agit d'un projet de logiciel libre publié sous la licence MIT et vous pouvez l'utiliser pour vos propres besoins. Veuillez consulter le lien ici-haut pour accéder au répertoire du projet.

Nous vous prions de bien vouloir inclure la licence et attribuer le travail où cela est requis.

Qu'est-ce que l'évaluation d'impact algorithmique?

L'EIA est un questionnaire conçu pour vous aider à évaluer et à atténuer les risques associés au déploiement d'un système de prise de décision automatisé. L'EIA permet également d'identifier le niveau d'impact de votre système de décision automatisé en vertu de la directive proposée sur la prise de décision automatisée. Les questions portent sur vos processus métier, vos données et vos décisions de conception de système.

Comment ça marche?

Ce questionnaire vous demande environ 60 questions liées à vos processus métier, à vos données et à vos décisions en matière de système. Les résultats démontreront votre niveau d'impact ainsi qu'un lien vous permettant de connaître vos exigences en vertu de la directive. Le questionnaire prend plus de 35 minutes à compléter.

Où puis-je savoir pourquoi mon système a été évalué à un certain niveau?

Lorsque vous aurez complété le questionnaire, une page de résultats détaillés vous sera présentée. Vous pouvez imprimer la page ou encore l'enregistrer en format PDF

Davantage de fonctionnalités seront ajoutées dans le futur afin de vous permettre de sauvegarder vos résultats.

Puis-je sauvegarder mes réponses et remplir le questionnaire plus tard?

Oui. Lorsque vous voulez sauvegarder votre progrès, cliquez sur le bouton 'Sauvegarder' en haut de la fenêtre et enregistrez le fichier JSON (un format texte structuré). Si vous voulez poursuivre à partir d'une sauvegarde, cliquez sur 'Choisir un fichier' et choisissez votre fichier JSON.

Est-ce que vous sauvegardez mes réponses?

Non, nous ne stockons pas vos réponses et les données saisies résident uniquement dans votre ordinateur. N'hésitez pas à utiliser cet outil autant de fois que nécessaire pendant le développement de votre système.

Toutes les données saisies seront instantanément effacées si vous cliquez sur le bouton 'Recommencer'.
html.default:
Purpose of this tool:Teams can use this tool to assess the alignment of their digital project against the GC Digital Standards. This tool is a work in progress and will continue to be updated as we receive feedback on it.

How to use this tool:At regular intervals go through the list of Standards and associated behaviours and activities that demonstrate “what good digital looks like” in the first column.

Finally, make a note of any questions you have about particular Standards and their associated behaviours, as well as any challenges you’ve encountered in trying to demonstrate the Standards. The Digital Change team at TBS can help you find colleagues with experience and expertise in particular areas associated with a Standard and can put you in touch for coaching, advice and learning opportunities.

Format:Each standard is subdivided into two sections. The first is Desirable Behaviour, which is a set of behaviours that align with the standard. The second section, Undesirable Behaviour, are examples behaviours which go against the spirit of the standard.

Intent: These questions will be turned into a survey. Each section will have a total score. For the MVP, the results will be downloadable and made available to those who take the self-assessment. Post MVP, the intent is to give the users the option for their data to persist, so that we may begin doing comparative analysis to identify which behaviours are most closely associated with high performance. Further questions will be required to define ‘high performance’ as a measure against which to properly weight the questions.

Implementation: The below content found in the Desirable Behaviour section is intended to be transitioned into a survey, which will allow scoring against each Digital Standard. The work is currently in progress, though an example of the rough format can be viewed here. Each question will be scored using the likert scale from 1-7.

Further Reading: For further context for each Digital Standard please refer to this link from canada.ca

pages.description: Please select the sections from which you would like to be evaluated against. By default all of them are enabled.

pages.name: sectionOneDesirableBehaviour

elements.name: question1
elements.title: End-user feedback is used to establish the requirements of our service(s).

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Our team has processes or tools in place for user feedback, including anonymous user feedback, to be incorporated into the design of the service.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: Our team conducts user research prior to deciding upon a given implementation.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: Our team has tested our primary systems in the users’ context with a wide range of users including users with varying needs and representing diverse backgrounds.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: Our team considers user needs and feedback in defining key service metrics.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: Our team uses automation to anticipate and detect operational or quality-of-service issues before our users tell us.

elements.name: question7
elements.title: Our team has within it, or direct access to, the expertise required to conduct user research and usability testing.

pages.title: Section One - Design with users

pages.name: sectionOneUndesirableBehaviour

elements.name: question8
elements.title: Our team receives requirements through extensive documentation and builds against them.

elements.name: question9
elements.title: Our team does not involve internal or external users to collaborate on the design of the service.

elements.name: question10
elements.title: The technical development resources or IT senior management are prioritizing features.

elements.name: question11
elements.title: Our team's prioritization of tasks is driven by senior management.

elements.name: question12
elements.title: Senior executives and teams rely exclusively on desk-based research, or other proxy sources of information to inform policy, program and/or service design.

pages.title: Section One - Design with users

pages.name: sectionTwoDesirableBehaviour

elements.name: question13
elements.title: There are processes in place to prioritize and implement feedback from peers, stakeholders and end-users.

elements.name: question14
elements.title: When a new or updated service or feature is being created our team understands the minimum requirements for the system to be of value to users.

elements.name: question15
elements.title: Our team experiments with new approaches based on team reflections, lessons learned, and user feedback.

elements.name: question16
elements.title: Our team collects metrics to improve upon which are used throughout the development and lifecycle of the service.

elements.name: question17
elements.title: When resolving problems our team dedicates time to identify the root cause of the issue and address it.

elements.name: question18
elements.title: Our team is relentlessly inspecting, adapting, and automating their processes to increase the speed at which our team can deliver value to users.

elements.name: question19
elements.title: Our team has access to environments and resources to allow for rapid prototyping while initial requirements are being sought.

elements.name: question20
elements.title: Our team embraces learning about and using new digital skills, approaches, and tools to incorporate into our daily work.

pages.title: Section Two - Iterate and Improve Frequently

pages.name: sectionTwoUndesirableBehaviour

elements.name: question21
elements.title: Our team only shares their work once it has been finalized and approved.

elements.name: question22
elements.title: Decisions regarding the direction of our team are made without reference to any collected performance metrics.

elements.name: question23
elements.title: Our team identifies solutions before it is clear what outcomes our team is working towards and how to measure them.

elements.name: question24
elements.title: Processes are rarely, if ever, reviewed to find and implement efficiencies.

elements.name: question25
elements.title: Our team must wait for the project to be approved and funded prior to environments being made available to teams to begin experimenting with solutions.

elements.name: question26
elements.title: Our team fully architects the end to the service delivery solution prior to starting to build.

pages.title: Section Two - Iterate and Improve Frequently

pages.name: sectionThreeDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question27
elements.title: Our team prioritizes solutions using open standards over solutions that do not.

elements.name: question28
elements.title: Team members give back to the open source community as active contributors.

elements.name: question29
elements.title: Our team designs their services to be interoperable with other services.

elements.name: question30
elements.title: When searching for a new product, service or solution, our team considers open source solutions.

elements.name: question31
elements.title: Our team supports clients using any device, from anywhere and at any time.

pages.title: Section Three - Use open standards and solutions

pages.name: sectionThreeUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question32
elements.title: Our team renews existing contracts with vendors without first investigating open source tooling.

elements.name: question33
elements.title: Our team does not have the competencies within it to deliver its services without the help of consultants or closed source vendor software.

pages.title: Section Three - Use open standards and solutions

pages.name: sectionFourDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question34
elements.title: Our team considers security and privacy throughout the service design process.

elements.name: question35
elements.title: When implementing or enforcing security or privacy controls, our team takes into consideration how they would impact the quality or efficiency of the service and how it will impact the end users of the service.

elements.name: question36
elements.title: Security measures are frictionless so that they do not place a burden on users.

elements.name: question37
elements.title: Our team has privacy and security knowledge and understanding as a competency within the team.

elements.name: question38
elements.title: The service has implemented automated security checks and privacy protections include role-based access and audit functions against the service.

elements.name: question39
elements.title: There are procedures and processes in place to quickly respond to security or privacy breaches or incidents.

pages.title: Section Four - Address security and privacy risks

pages.name: sectionFourUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question40
elements.title: Team has no internal privacy or security knowledge, relying on other teams to identify nearly all security or privacy controls and best practices.

elements.name: question41
elements.title: The core services upon which our team works have no automated security checks or privacy protections.

elements.name: question42
elements.title: Our team relies on security through obscurity, hiding services or information rather than improving the security posture of the service.

elements.name: question43
elements.title: Our team implements or enforces security or privacy controls without considering the impact on service usability.

pages.title: Section Four - Address security and privacy risks

pages.name: sectionFiveDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question44
elements.title: Starting at the outset, our team's service and platform design continually considers the lowest levels of digital skill, confidence and access.

elements.name: question45
elements.title: Our team understands how to make their services or products accessible.

elements.name: question46
elements.title: The need for accessibility is considered during the initial service design

elements.name: question47
elements.title: Research and testing are conducted to ensure our service is accessible to people of all abilities no matter how, where, or when they access the service.

elements.name: question48
elements.title: Our team conducts ongoing user research with users with low level digital literacy, people with disability, and people from different cultural and linguistic backgrounds.

elements.name: question49
elements.title: Our team implements automated accessibility checks for our services.

pages.title: Section Five - Build in accessibility from the start

pages.name: sectionFiveUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question50
elements.title: Our team has no competency with accessibility and relies on another team to identify accessibility shortcomings.

elements.name: question51
elements.title: Accessibility compliance is added at the end of the development cycle in order to pass compliance checks or audits.

pages.title: Section Five - Build in accessibility from the start

pages.name: sectionSixDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question52
elements.title: Our team strives to leverage data to continuously improve decision-making, operations, or service delivery.

elements.name: question53
elements.title: Our team identifies what data is needed to support decision-making, operations, or service delivery and reuses existing data as appropriate before acquiring new data.

elements.name: question54
elements.title: Our team strives to identify and remove barriers to data sharing and release.

elements.name: question55
elements.title: Our team ensures that users of our services can make corrections to their personal information.

elements.name: question56
elements.title: Our team publishes data and information on the open government portal.

elements.name: question57
elements.title: Our team publishes data in plain language and machine-readable formats.

elements.name: question58
elements.title: Our team has clearly defined roles, responsibilities, and accountabilities for data and information management and use.

elements.name: question59
elements.title: Our team captures appropriate metadata to provide context for the information and data we create and capture, thereby enabling its discovery and reuse by others.

elements.name: question60
elements.title: Our team has processes in place to regularly assess, maintain, and improve data quality.

elements.name: question61
elements.title: Our service has in place processes for ensuring proper management of information and data prior to being collected, used, disclosed, retained, disposed of, or declassified.

elements.name: question62
elements.title: Our team ensures that information and data of business value are saved in systems where it can be properly managed.

elements.name: question63
elements.title: Our team has processes in place for determining the classification of data and information.

elements.name: question64
elements.title: Our team is aware of which information and data has business value and prioritizes its management.

pages.title: Section Six - Be good data stewards

pages.name: sectionSixUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question65
elements.title: Our team, or the service our team manages, asks users for the same information more than once.

elements.name: question66
elements.title: The service, or services, our team is responsible for collects all the data or information required without reusing existing data or information.

elements.name: question67
elements.title: The documentation for our APIs is only available to internal approved consumers.

elements.name: question68
elements.title: Our team does not have the data it needs to make informed policy, program, or service decisions.

pages.title: Section Six - Be good data stewards

pages.name: sectionSevenDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question69
elements.title: Our team continually seeks out indicators of bias and ensures their services are not reinforcing unintended biases.

elements.name: question70
elements.title: Our team continually seeks out evidence of unintended consequences to the user in service design and delivery and works to mitigate these consequences for the user.

elements.name: question71
elements.title: When automated decision-making is being leveraged by our team, possible biases in the data and algorithms are acknowledged, accounted for, and mitigated.

elements.name: question72
elements.title: Our team designs services which address cultural, linguistic, geographical, disability, technological, socioeconomic, or other access barriers to uptake.

elements.name: question73
elements.title: Our team has considered the impacts of decisions on the users and negative outcomes are reduced, when encountered.

elements.name: question74
elements.title: Our team uses data in a manner consistent with the purpose of its collection.

pages.title: Section Seven - Design ethical services

pages.name: sectionSevenUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question75
elements.title: No training is provided to our team regarding the potential impacts of the service they are designing or delivering.

elements.name: question76
elements.title: Our team conducts little to no monitoring of outcomes of the service to identify implicit bias.

elements.name: question77
elements.title: Our team delegates ethical analysis to a vendor or external service, without direct accountability to management.

elements.name: question78
elements.title: Our team designs and deliver services without fully considering relevant legislation

elements.name: question79
elements.title: Our team delivers services without assessing the impacts of negative outcomes.

pages.title: Section Seven - Design ethical services

pages.name: sectionEightDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question80
elements.title: Our team is multidisciplinary, having all the skills and capabilities required to fully deliver our service to users.

elements.name: question81
elements.title: Our team is active in communities of practice, events, or groups that pertain to the areas of expertise of team members.

elements.name: question82
elements.title: Our team has identified, and collaborates with, other teams, in or outside of our organisation, including other levels of government, other governments, the public, or private sector organizations, who have done, or are doing, similar work.

elements.name: question83
elements.title: Our team documents any APIs for our service using modern and common protocols and standards and provides examples to others regarding their use.

elements.name: question84
elements.title: Our team uses data from performance monitoring tools to inform business decisions.

pages.title: Section Eight - Collaborate widely

pages.name: sectionEightUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question85
elements.title: Our team develops most of the service on our own, without leveraging existing solutions and services to reduce duplication of effort.

elements.name: question86
elements.title: Our team overwhelmingly relies on tickets to manage collaboration between internal stakeholders or teams.

elements.name: question87
elements.title: The team does not consider the impacts on teams working across the value stream, or on the outcome of the service.

pages.title: Section Eight - Collaborate widely

pages.name: sectionNineDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question88
elements.title: Team members self-organize and self-manage through self-assigning tasks.

elements.name: question89
elements.title: Team members meet with liberty to openly discuss challenges without fear of blame or reproach.

elements.name: question90
elements.title: Team members feel safe to challenge the status quo.

elements.name: question91
elements.title: Our team values learning as part of daily work.

elements.name: question92
elements.title: Team members can articulate how their work contributes to business outcomes.

elements.name: question93
elements.title: Our team can choose the tools they use to deliver their service.

elements.name: question94
elements.title: Our team's management actively removes impediments that prevent the team from focusing on delivering value.

elements.name: question95
elements.title: Our team has access to environments to experiment with new approaches, tooling, or solutions.

elements.name: question96
elements.title: Our team feels their feedback is valued.

elements.name: question97
elements.title: Failures are treated in our team as opportunities to improve and learn.

pages.title: Section Nine - Empower staff to deliver better services

pages.name: sectionNineUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question98
elements.title: Work is assigned directly to members of our team from management.

elements.name: question99
elements.title: Our team is required to get a series of approvals prior to being able to make routine changes to their service.

elements.name: question100
elements.title: Learning in our team is largely done through week or day long courses periodically throughout the year.

elements.name: question101
elements.title: Our team is unable, or finds it difficult, to acquire productivity tooling.

elements.name: question102
elements.title: Our team does not have access to Software as a Service (SaaS) productivity tools as they are blocked by the department.

elements.name: question103
elements.title: On our team, learning through reading books, blogs, or watching videos, talks, or tutorials is not viewed as work.

elements.name: question104
elements.title: Our team has restricted access to tools, training and software based on job classification.

pages.title: Section Nine - Empower staff to deliver better services

pages.name: sectionTenDesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question105
elements.title: Teams continually makes all non-sensitive and non-personal data, information, and new code publicly available, or at a minimum accessible across the GC, for sharing and reuse.

elements.name: question106
elements.title: Our team contributes back to the public projects from which they borrow content.

elements.name: question107
elements.title: Our team tracks and makes public the metrics upon which our team measures its success.

elements.name: question108
elements.title: Our team tracks, and makes publicly available, or at a minimum accessible across the GC, information regarding how often a change to our services fails (e.g., the deployment or rollout of a service or feature experiences issues or complications).

elements.name: question109
elements.title: Our team makes visual displays which show what they’re working on and the status of their work available publicly, or at least throughout the Government of Canada.

elements.name: question110
elements.title: Our team publicly documents, including examples of reuse, how others can use their service’s APIs, open data, or information.

pages.title: Section Ten - Work in the open by default

pages.name: sectionTenUndesirableBehaviours

elements.name: question111
elements.title: All of the team's work is done on systems behind the corporate firewall.

elements.name: question112
elements.title: The work of our team has permissions set so that only members of our team can access the team's work.

elements.name: question113
elements.title: Our team does not contribute to, or collaborate on, work being done by our colleagues.

elements.name: question114
elements.title: Team applies blanket security classification for the digital system to all data stored by the application.

elements.name: question115
elements.title: Our team has no process by which to declassify and release records when they are no longer protected or classified.

elements.name: question116
elements.title: The documentation for our APIs is only available to internal approved consumers.

pages.title: Section Ten - Work in the open by default
